newsitem.title: UK: BTR warns on profits, shares slump.
newsitem.headline: BTR warns on profits, shares slump.

text.p: BTR Plc, Britain's biggest conglomerate, saw its shares nosedive Thursday after it issued a profit warning just as the market believed the company had the worst behind it.

The widely diversified conglomerate, which is in the final stages of a major restructuring, said the pound sterling's strength would hurt first-half 1997 sales by 300 million pounds ($486.7 million), if the currency stayed at its current high levels.
The impact on operating profits would be about 35 million pounds ($56.8 million), said BTR, which focuses on industrial manufacturing and engineering operations.
The profit warning comes just two months after BTR reported better-than-expected 1996 results and said it was making good progress in getting its act together.
BTR shares dropped 31.5 pence (51 cents), or 12 percent, to 2.36 pounds ($3.83) in late morning trade after they shot up early in March on the favourable full-year results.
Analysts reduced their profit estimates for this year by about 10 percent to around 1.2 billion pounds ($1.9 billion).
"Even without sterling, the company is still facing large problems in some of its markets and with some of its products," said one analyst.
BTR's profit warning also showed that the conglomerate's restructuring, which already saw the weeding out of many of its underperforming operations, is not complete yet.
"They are turning things around, but it is a big ship to turn -- it will take time," said this industry watcher.
